title: Serena Williams Advances to the U.S. Open Final
text:
In Serena Williams’s yearlong-plus comeback from childbirth, she’s come oh-so-close to clinching tennis’s most prestigious record. She’s made the Wimbledon final twice and the U.S. Open final last year, falling to rising star Naomi Osaka.

Now, with the top-seeded Osaka out of the U.S. Open, Williams is one win away from tying Margaret Court’s Grand Slam singles titles record of 24.

On Thursday, the 8th-seeded Williams dispensed with her penultimate opponent in the Open, the fast-climbing No. 5 seed Elina Svitolina of Ukraine, 6-3, 6-1, to advance to Saturday’s final.

Williams will play No. 15 seed Bianca Andreescu, who beat No. 13 seed Belinda Bencic of Switzerland in the late Thursday semifinal, for another shot at the Grand Slam titles record.

“Is this the best opportunity? I don’t know,” Williams said. “I literally haven’t thought about it this tournament. I’ve been way more chill.”

Williams won the 2017 Australian Open then took a year off to give birth to her daughter, Olympia. Williams hasn’t won a Grand Slam title since coming back.

“It’s not easy to go through what I did and come back—and so fast,” Williams said. “To keep playing, to also not be 20 years old, yeah, I’m pretty proud of myself.”

By her high standards, Williams has been uneven in this Open. She thwacked Maria Sharapova 6-1, 6-1 in the first round but looked shaky in the second round, dropping the first set to unseeded Caty McNally. Then Williams blasted past No. 18 seed Qiang Wang in 44 minutes in Tuesday’s quarterfinal.

Williams wasn’t quite as dominant Thursday. But she tightened her focus when needed, hitting 33 winners and winning three of seven break points.

“That’s why she is who she is,” Svitolina said. “You are playing in front of the best tennis player in the world. If you don’t take it she just grabs it. There’s no chance to take it back.”

Svitolina won her most recent previous matchup with Williams, in the third round of the 2016 Rio Olympics, after losing their previous four matchups. Since those Olympics, Svitolina has made a sturdy run toward the top. She reached the quarterfinals of the 2017 French Open and of the Australian in 2018 and this year.

At Wimbledon this year she reached the semifinals of a major for the first time, losing to eventual champion Simona Halep.

Bianca Andreescu plays Serena Williams for the U.S. Open title on Saturday. Photo: Clive Brunskill/Getty Images

Entering Thursday’s match, Svitolina hadn’t lost a set in this Open. But on Thursday she looked tentative, defensively drifting behind the baseline against Williams’s booming ground strokes as Williams took control of the match.

Williams had just smashed a winner to break Svitolina in her first service game, then started the next game with a service winner.

“Do that again!” someone in the crowd yelled. She hit an ace.

Williams followed that up by hitting a cross-court shot that Svitolina swung at and missed like a slumping shortstop. Soon after, Williams was up three games to zero.

“I don’t think she played amazing today, but she played a very high level at the beginning,” Svitolina said.

Williams’s biggest competition in challenging Court’s record might be time. Andreescu, at age 19, is roughly half Williams’s age. She turns 38 on Sept. 26. Andreescu played a fierce match Thursday, winning a first-set tiebreak then breaking Bencic to win the second set, 7-6(3), 7-5.

Andreescu is poised beyond her years. In August, after Williams withdrew with an injury from the Rogers Cup final match against Andreescu, Williams sat courtside in tears. Andreescu hugged and comforted her, saying, “Don’t even get me started. I’ve watched you your whole career. You’re a f---ing beast.”

Williams is nearly seven years older than Court was when she won her last Grand Slam title: the 1973 U.S. Open.

But Williams has made a career of jaw-dropping, logic-defying maneuvers. A nearly 38-year-old mother isn’t supposed to be ushering early-20somethings off the court. But here we are.

By the second set Thursday, in the crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium, singer Queen Latifah was throwing her head back and smiling at Williams’s winners. Tennis’s queen is making another run.

Write to Rachel Bachman at rachel.bachman@wsj.com
description: Serena Williams beat Elina Svitolina 6-3, 6-1, to advance to Saturday’s U.S. Open final. Williams faces Bianca Andreescu in the final.
